items.title: Israel says latest remains returned from Gaza are not bodies of hostages
items.standfirst: The Israeli military said Saturday that the remains of three people handed over by Hamas to the Red Cross this week do not belong to any of the remaining Israeli hostages. Palestinian militants have released the remains of 17 hostages they held in Gaza, but the handover of the bodies of the 11 remaining hostages has been slow.
items.content: The Israeli military said Saturday that the remains of three people handed over by Hamas to the Red Cross this week do not belong to any of the remaining Israeli hostages. Palestinian militants have released the remains of 17 hostages they held in Gaza, but the handover of the bodies of the 11 remaining hostages has been slow.

items.content: President Donald Trump is touting an international force to help bring peace to the shattered Gaza Strip and see that all deceased hostages held by Hamas are returned to Israel.

items.standfirst: Remains of Amiram Cooper and Sahar Baruch returned to Israel for burial after identification process, Israeli military saidHamas handed over two bodies of deceased Israeli hostages on Thursday, a day after the tenuous Gaza ceasefire was shaken by deadly Israeli strikes across the strip.The bodies of the hostages Amiram Cooper and Sahar Baruch were returned to Israel for burial after an identification process was completed, the Israeli military said late on Thursday. items.title: Era of free trade and investment is over, Canada’s PM tells Apec summit
items.standfirst: Mark Carney warns Asia-Pacific leaders global economy undergoing profound change, as China’s president mounts defence of free tradeThe Canadian prime minister, Mark Carney, has warned that the era of free trade and investment that formed the foundations of the postwar global economy has ended.In a stark message to Asia-Pacific leaders at the Apec summit in South Korea on Friday, Carney said rules-based open trade no longer worked in a global economy that was undergoing one of its most profound periods of change since the fall of the Berlin Wall in 1989. Continue reading...
items.content: Mark Carney warns Asia-Pacific leaders global economy undergoing profound change, as China’s president mounts defence of free tradeThe Canadian prime minister, Mark Carney, has warned that the era of free trade and investment that formed the foundations of the postwar global economy has ended.In a stark message to Asia-Pacific leaders at the Apec summit in South Korea on Friday, Carney said rules-based open trade no longer worked in a global economy that was undergoing one of its most profound periods of change since the fall of the Berlin Wall in 1989. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney apologized to President Trump.
The apology was for an anti-tariff ad featuring Ronald Reagan.
Trump ended trade talks with Canada after the ad aired.
Carney told Ontario's premier not to run the advertisement.
Trump claimed the ad interfered with a Supreme Court decision.

items.title: Uncertainty over federal food aid rises as shutdown fight continues

items.content: Rulings by two federal judges eased pressure on SNAP benefits, although President Trump said payments are likely to be delayed.

items.title: US govt ‘taking trillions of dollars out of social safety net’, NGO says
items.standfirst: The prolonged government shutdown in the United States has deepened nationwide hardships as delayed food assistance, rising health insurance costs, and stalled political negotiations leave millions of Americans struggling to meet basic needs. FRANCE 24 speaks to Aaron Czyzewski, director of advocacy and public policy at Food Lifeline, to get a better grasp of the situation.
items.content: The prolonged government shutdown in the United States has deepened nationwide hardships as delayed food assistance, rising health insurance costs, and stalled political negotiations leave millions of Americans struggling to meet basic needs. FRANCE 24 speaks to Aaron Czyzewski, director of advocacy and public policy at Food Lifeline, to get a better grasp of the situation.

items.title: Uncertainty over federal food aid deepens as the shutdown fight reaches a crisis point
items.standfirst: The crises at the heart of the government shutdown fight in Washington were coming to a head Saturday as the federal food assistance program faced delays and millions of Americans were set to see a dramatic rise in their health insurance bills. The impacts on basic needs — food and medical care —…
items.content: The crises at the heart of the government shutdown fight in Washington were coming to a head Saturday as the federal food assistance program faced delays and millions of Americans were set to see a dramatic rise in their health insurance bills. The impacts on basic needs — food and medical care —…

items.title: US government shutdown: Americans face food aid delays and soaring health costs
items.standfirst: The crises at the heart of the government shutdown fight in Washington were coming to a head Saturday as the federal food assistance program faced delays and millions of Americans were set to see a dramatic rise in their health insurance bills. The impacts on basic needs — food and medical care — underscored how the impasse is hitting homes across the United States. The Trump administration's plans to freeze payments to the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program on Saturday were halted by federal judges, but the delay in payouts will still likely leave millions of people short on their grocery bills.
items.content: The crises at the heart of the government shutdown fight in Washington were coming to a head Saturday as the federal food assistance program faced delays and millions of Americans were set to see a dramatic rise in their health insurance bills. The impacts on basic needs — food and medical care — underscored how the impasse is hitting homes across the United States. The Trump administration's plans to freeze payments to the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program on Saturday were halted by federal judges, but the delay in payouts will still likely leave millions of people short on their grocery bills.

items.title: Poor Americans face food aid delay during government shutdown

items.content: Billions in ‘Snap’ nutritional assistance programme benefits are stalled despite court orders

items.title: With the outlook for SNAP benefits uncertain, food banks are warning of a crisis

items.content: More Americans are turning to food banks to help fill the assistance gap, but administrators caution they aren't designed to act as a safety net for a government program.(Image credit: Matthew Hatcher)

ai_summary: Judges ruled against cutting off SNAP food benefits.
President Trump said payments are likely to be delayed.
The government shutdown is causing food aid delays.
Millions of Americans face rising health insurance costs.
An NGO says the government is taking trillions from social safety net.

items.title: Tanzanian president wins disputed election with more than 97% of the vote

items.title: Tanzania’s Hassan declared landslide winner in election that triggered violent protests
items.standfirst: The result hands Hassan, who took power in 2021, a five-year term following opposition repressionTanzania’s president, Samia Suluhu Hassan, has been declared the winner of the country’s disputed election with more than 97% of the vote following violent protests across the country earlier in the week.The landslide result announced by Tanzania’s electoral commission hands Hassan, who took power in 2021 after the death in office of her predecessor, a five-year term to govern the east African country of 68 million people. Continue reading...

clusters.title: Egypt's Grand Museum opens, displaying Tutankhamun tomb in full for first time

items.title: Egypt's Grand Museum opens, displaying Tutankhamun tomb in full for first time
items.standfirst: The launch of the billion-dollar site sees fresh calls for the return of antiquities held in museums overseas.
items.content: The launch of the billion-dollar site sees fresh calls for the return of antiquities held in museums overseas.

items.title: Grand Egyptian Museum a 'symbol' to be shared with world
items.standfirst: Egypt was inaugurating the long-delayed Grand Egyptian Museum (GEM) on Saturday, the world’s largest museum dedicated to its ancient civilization. World leaders, including monarchs, heads of states and governments, were to attend the grand opening ceremony in Cairo. "This (GEM) is a symbol of Egypt, but it's a symbol that Egypt wants to share", FRANCE 24's Nurla Teson said, reporting from Cairo.
items.content: Egypt was inaugurating the long-delayed Grand Egyptian Museum (GEM) on Saturday, the world’s largest museum dedicated to its ancient civilization. World leaders, including monarchs, heads of states and governments, were to attend the grand opening ceremony in Cairo. "This (GEM) is a symbol of Egypt, but it's a symbol that Egypt wants to share", FRANCE 24's Nurla Teson said, reporting from Cairo.

items.title: Watch live: Egypt unveils Grand Egyptian Museum dedicated to its ancient civilization
items.standfirst: Saturday marks the innauguration of Cairo’s Grand Egyptian Museum (GEM) – the world’s largest museum dedicated to an ancient civilization. It is expected to attract 5 million visitors annually, which would put it in the ranks of the most popular museums in the world. Watch our special coverage of the museum's inauguration live on FRANCE 24 from 6pm Paris time (GMT+1).
items.content: Saturday marks the innauguration of Cairo’s Grand Egyptian Museum (GEM) – the world’s largest museum dedicated to an ancient civilization. It is expected to attract 5 million visitors annually, which would put it in the ranks of the most popular museums in the world. Watch our special coverage of the museum's inauguration live on FRANCE 24 from 6pm Paris time (GMT+1).

items.title: Egypt unveils Grand Egyptian Museum dedicated to its ancient civilisation

items.content: Two halls are dedicated to the 5,000 artefacts from the collection of King Tutankhamun.

items.content: A trove of golden treasures and antiquities detailing life in ancient Egypt will go on public display at Cairo's record-breaking new museum.

clusters.title: Serbia protests: ‘The people are angry, the people want justice’, expert says
clusters.neutral_headline: Serbians Protest Train Station Disaster Anniversary

items.title: Serbia protests: ‘The people are angry, the people want justice’, expert says
items.standfirst: Tens of thousands of protesters poured into Serbia's second city on Saturday a year after a railway station roof collapse that killed 16 people, unleashing discontent over alleged corruption and a lack of accountability many blame for the disaster. FRANCE 24 speaks to Helena Ivanov, associate research fellow at the Henry Jackson Society, to shed more light on the situation.
items.content: Tens of thousands of protesters poured into Serbia's second city on Saturday a year after a railway station roof collapse that killed 16 people, unleashing discontent over alleged corruption and a lack of accountability many blame for the disaster. FRANCE 24 speaks to Helena Ivanov, associate research fellow at the Henry Jackson Society, to shed more light on the situation.

items.title: Serbians rally to mark anniversary of deadly train station roof collapse
items.standfirst: Tens of thousands of people from all over Serbia gathered on Saturday in the northern town of Novi Sad to commemorate the victims of a railway station disaster a year ago. The rally was also a massive display of boiling discontent with the government of autocratic President Aleksandar Vucic. The collapse of a concrete canopy at the Novi Sad train station last Nov. 1 killed 16 people. The tragedy triggered youth-led street protests and a nationwide movement demanding political changes that have seriously shaken Vucic's tight hold on power.
items.content: Tens of thousands of people from all over Serbia gathered on Saturday in the northern town of Novi Sad to commemorate the victims of a railway station disaster a year ago. The rally was also a massive display of boiling discontent with the government of autocratic President Aleksandar Vucic. The collapse of a concrete canopy at the Novi Sad train station last Nov. 1 killed 16 people. The tragedy triggered youth-led street protests and a nationwide movement demanding political changes that have seriously shaken Vucic's tight hold on power.

items.title: Huge crowds gather on first anniversary of Serbian train station disaster
items.standfirst: Student-led movement continues to demand political change as embattled president issues rare apologyTens of thousands of Serbians have gathered to commemorate victims of a fatal railway station collapse a year ago, a tragedy that galvanised anti-government sentiment that still threatens the embattled president, Aleksandar Vučić.A student-led movement organised the rallies in the country’s second largest city, Novi Sad, where on 1 November 2024, the canopy at the newly renovated railway station collapsed. Continue reading...
items.content: Student-led movement continues to demand political change as embattled president issues rare apologyTens of thousands of Serbians have gathered to commemorate victims of a fatal railway station collapse a year ago, a tragedy that galvanised anti-government sentiment that still threatens the embattled president, Aleksandar Vučić.A student-led movement organised the rallies in the country’s second largest city, Novi Sad, where on 1 November 2024, the canopy at the newly renovated railway station collapsed. Continue reading...

items.title: Serbians stage mass rally to mark first anniversary of deadly train station collapse
items.standfirst: Tens of thousands of Serbians on Saturday demonstrated to mark the first anniversary of a deadly railway station roof collapse that killed 16 people in Novi Sad, the country’s second largest city. The accident sparked a wave of student-led protests against the administration of Serbian President Aleksandar Vucic.
items.content: Tens of thousands of Serbians on Saturday demonstrated to mark the first anniversary of a deadly railway station roof collapse that killed 16 people in Novi Sad, the country’s second largest city. The accident sparked a wave of student-led protests against the administration of Serbian President Aleksandar Vucic.

items.content: Tens of thousands of people marked the first anniversary of a train station roof collapse in silence.

clusters.title: Flights delayed across US amid air traffic controller shortages as shutdown drags on
clusters.neutral_headline: Air Traffic Controller Shortages Cause Flight Delays

items.title: Flights delayed across US amid air traffic controller shortages as shutdown drags on
items.standfirst: Nearly 50% of 30 busiest airports facing absences as staff are forced to work without pay and shutdown hits 31st dayNearly 50% of the 30 busiest US airports faced shortages of air traffic controllers, the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) said on Friday, leading to flight delays nationwide as a federal government shutdown hit its 31st day.The absence of controllers on Friday is by far the most widespread since the shutdown began, with one of the worst-hit regions being New York, where 80% of air traffic controllers were out, the agency said. Continue reading...
items.content: Nearly 50% of 30 busiest airports facing absences as staff are forced to work without pay and shutdown hits 31st dayNearly 50% of the 30 busiest US airports faced shortages of air traffic controllers, the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) said on Friday, leading to flight delays nationwide as a federal government shutdown hit its 31st day.The absence of controllers on Friday is by far the most widespread since the shutdown began, with one of the worst-hit regions being New York, where 80% of air traffic controllers were out, the agency said. Continue reading...

items.standfirst: In Chicago suburb, protesters confront ICE agents, whom Evanston mayor says ‘assaulted’ residentsDonald Trump’s immigration crackdown continued on Halloween night as federal agents were seen in Chicago and Los Angeles on the holiday, according to multiple reports.In Chicago, where the president has unleashed military troops to assist Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) as agents carry out arrests and push back against protesters, several people were arrested on Friday. clusters.title: Senate passes bill to nullify Trump’s sweeping global tariffs on more than 100 nations – as it happened
clusters.neutral_headline: Senate Votes to Reject Trump's Global Tariffs

items.title: Senate passes bill to nullify Trump’s sweeping global tariffs on more than 100 nations – as it happened
items.standfirst: This live blog is now closed.Trump news at a glance: Four Senate Republicans join Democrats to reject global tariffsIn the days leading up to the Trump-Xi meeting, American officials signalled that the US president did not intend to make good on a recent threat to impose an additional 100% import tax on Chinese goods.Also that China had shown signs it is willing to relax its export controls on rare earths as well as revive buying soybeans from the US.The relationship with China is very good.Because of the tremendous destructive power, I HATED to do it, but had no choice! Russia is second, and China is a distant third, but will be even within 5 years.Because of other countries testing programs, I have instructed the Department of War to start testing our Nuclear Weapons on an equal basis. That process will begin immediately. Continue reading...
items.content: This live blog is now closed.Trump news at a glance: Four Senate Republicans join Democrats to reject global tariffsIn the days leading up to the Trump-Xi meeting, American officials signalled that the US president did not intend to make good on a recent threat to impose an additional 100% import tax on Chinese goods.Also that China had shown signs it is willing to relax its export controls on rare earths as well as revive buying soybeans from the US.The relationship with China is very good.Because of the tremendous destructive power, I HATED to do it, but had no choice! Russia is second, and China is a distant third, but will be even within 5 years.Because of other countries testing programs, I have instructed the Department of War to start testing our Nuclear Weapons on an equal basis. That process will begin immediately. Continue reading...

items.title: US Senate votes to reject Trump’s global tariffs on more than 100 countries
items.standfirst: Vote passes 51-47 in latest bipartisan effort to challenge tariffs, but House is unlikely to take any similar actionThe US Senate took a stand against Donald Trump’s global tariffs affecting more than 100 countries on Thursday, voting to nullify the so-called “reciprocal” tariffs.Four Republicans joined with all Democrats to vote 51-47 on a resolution to end the base-level tariffs that the president put into place via executive order. Continue reading...
items.content: Vote passes 51-47 in latest bipartisan effort to challenge tariffs, but House is unlikely to take any similar actionThe US Senate took a stand against Donald Trump’s global tariffs affecting more than 100 countries on Thursday, voting to nullify the so-called “reciprocal” tariffs.Four Republicans joined with all Democrats to vote 51-47 on a resolution to end the base-level tariffs that the president put into place via executive order. Continue reading...

ai_summary: The Senate passed a bill to nullify Trump's global tariffs on over 100 nations.
Four Republicans joined Democrats to reject the tariffs.
The vote was 51-47 in favor of ending the tariffs.
The House is unlikely to take similar action.
The tariffs were put in place via executive order.
